En el sector donde viven es un lugar de turismo que son la laguna de yahuarcocha y también la mayoría de gente se dedican al comercio, agricultura y la gente de esa zona son muy hospitalarias, amables y respetuosa.
Iván tiene su venta de Cds de músicas y videos desde hace 12 años atrás la cual ha sido su fuente de ingreso para todas las necesidades que se le ha presentado en su vida, el negocio aprendió por iniciativa propia lo ejerce conjuntamente con su esposa las ventas lo realiza en el puesto que mantiene en el mercado de Atuntaqui.
Con el crédito que solicito lo va invertir en la compra de más cds accesorios como flash, auriculares va incrementar la mercadería y así seguir ejerciendo la actividad que viene manteniendo hasta el día de hoy.
Agradece a Fundación Alternativa por todo el apoyo que ha brindado para seguir mejorando la calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Ivan is married and is 32 years old. His wife is 31 years old, and they have 2 children with whom they live in a family house in the neighborhood of La Florida, which is in the city of Ibarra, in the province of Imbabura. 

The area where they live is a place of tourism because of the Laguna de Yahuarcocha. Also, most of the people work in business and agriculture, and the people of the area are very hospitable, kind, and respectful.

Ivan has sold music CDs and DVDs for 12 years. Before, this has been his source of income for all of the things that have come up in his life. He learned the business through his own initiative, and he works in his business with his wife. He makes sales in a stand that he maintains in the market in Atuntaqui. 

With the loan he is requesting, he will invest in the purchase of more CDs, flash memory, and headphones. He is going to increase his merchandise and thus continue doing the work he has maintained to this day.

He is thankful to Fundación Alternativa for all of the support that they have offered to continue improving his quality of life.

loans.use: to buy more CDs, flash memory, and headphones to increase his merchandise and continue growing.

loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
Mirasol is a 37-year-old married woman. She has has four children who are in school.

Mirasol is in the agricultural business, fattening pigs in the Philippines. Mirasol requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Mirasol has been in pig fattening for two years now, and has borrowed four times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Mirasol would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Samvel

texts.en:
Samvel decided to cooperate with Kiva lenders for the first time with great hope that he will be supported. He lives with his family in Sevan city of Gergharkunik region. He has a son and a daughter; both of them are students.

Samvel worked for many years as an aquatic sports coach, and then he also worked as a physical education teacher at a school. Now he is a farmer, trying to cover his family’s financial needs through farming.

Samvel’s son studies at Gavar State University in the faculty of Jurisdiction at the paid division. Unfortunately Samvel now is short of money, when it is time to pay for his son’s education.

Samvel asks for this loan in an amount of 200,000 Armenian drams, as he must pay for his son’s tuition fee for the second semester.

loans.use: to pay for his son’s tuition fee for the second semester

loans.name: Women Of Thunder Group

texts.en:
Diana is a strong member of the Women of Thunder group. The Group consists of four women, most of them are in the same line of business and they are now taking their second loan from Thrive Microfinance. They have a desire to attain financial freedom and improve their standards of living.

Diana is a single mother with three dependents of whom two are of school going age. She sells eggs at wholesale prices and has been in this business since 2011. She got $300 in the last loan cycle and invested it in her business. From the profits, she managed to pay school fees for her children, buy food and pay utility bills.

She needs a loan of $500 which will be invested in her egg wholesaling business and will be committed to a $30 savings plan per month. Diana and her members are grateful with business training and financial support from Thrive and the funders on Kiva.

loans.use: To expand her wholesale egg supply business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase stock of threads, fancy cloths, sequins, and pearls of various colors.

loans.name: Nafry Jaime

texts.es:
Nafry, es un joven de 25 años de edad, es jornalero y estudió hasta tercer año de bachillerato, está casado y junto con su esposa tiene un hijo de 6 meses de edad, su esposa se dedica a los quehaceres de el hogar y al cuido de su hijo.

Nafry, tiene una platanera y trabaja como jornalero desde hace un año, este trabajo lo aprendió con unos amigos y por la necesidad economica en que vivia, no tenia para darle a su familia todo lo necesario.- Para llegar a la platanera tiene que viajar en su bicicleta 3 kilómteros y trabaja en el horario de 5:00 a.m. a 4:00 p.m. todos los dias.

El crédito que está solicitando en la Institucion es para comprar una refrigeradora, para que sus alimentos duren un poco más y no se arruinen.

El sueño de Nafry, es comprar una vivienda digna para su familia.
texts.en:
Nafry is a young man who is 25 years old. He is a day laborer and studied through the third year of his degree. He is married, and he and his wife have a 6-month-old son. His wife is dedicated to household tasks and to taking care of their son.

Nafry has a banana farm and has worked as a day laborer for one year. He learned this work with some friends because of his financial needs. He wasn’t able to give his family everything they needed. To arrive at the banana farm, he has to travel 3 kilometers by bicycle, and he works on a schedule from 5:00am to 4:00pm everyday.

The loan he is requesting from the Institution is to buy a refrigerator, so that his food lasts a little longer and don’t spoil. 

Nafry’s dream is to buy a dignified home for his family.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator.

loans.name: Takatendeka Group

texts.en:
Emily is a member of Takatendeka group, meaning (we are faithful) in their local language. Her group has 6 people and they have received a loan amounting to $4250 altogether to fund their individual businesses. Emily is a cross-border trader who specializes in buying beans in Zimbabwe and sell them in South Africa. She lives in Warren Park, a suburb of Harare. 

Emily and her group members joined Thrive Microfinance in 2013 and since that time she has been benefiting from Thrive program. She benefited a lot from getting funding from Thrive and she wishes to continue with this program as it is changing her life.

loans.use: to expand her business exporting beans to South Africa.

loans.name: Dunamis Power Group

texts.en:
Evermore is a hard working business woman and a mother of three children. Her two sons and her daughter help her in running her hairdressing business ever since she lost her husband in 2003. Her business has been improving at a snail’s pace because of the increasing cost of education for her children. She has been forced to complement the salon with selling clothes that she procures from South Africa, Tanzania and Botswana. 

Evermore is one of our success stories here at Thrive Microfinance. She has been able to extend her salon and provide more space, buy a heavy-duty drier, hair chemicals and other equipment necessary for her salon. Her children’s school fees are paid from the business profits. Evermore even has enough money left over to enjoy little luxuries, like milk for tea, which was once beyond her reach.

Her group, Dunamis Power consist of three other women, also committed to their businesses. She hopes that a loan amounting $800 from Kiva will help her acquire better hairdressing equipment to match the increasing demand from her customers.

loans.use: To buy more hair driers for her salon.

loans.name: Juan Antonio

texts.es:
Juan, de 36 años de edad, es jornalero, estudió hasta noveno grado, está acompañado y junto con su compañera de vida tiene 3 hijos de 16, 14 y 12 años de edad, sus hijos estudian en el centro educativo de la comunidad y su esposa se dedica a los que haceres del hogar.

Juan, trabaja cortando caña desde hace 10 años, trabajo que decidio aprenderlo por la misma necesidad que tenia y asi poder ayudarle a sus padres.- Para llegar a su trabajo camina algunos kilomteros, su horario es de 8:00 a.m. a 4:00 p.m. todos los dias.

El crédito que está solicitando en la institucion es para comprar utiles escolares para sus hijos.

El sueño de Juan, es que sus hijos estudien mucho, para que sean profecionales.
texts.en:
Juan, 36 years old, is a day laborer who studied up to the 9th grade. He has a spouse and with this life's companion, he has three children, ages 16, 14, and 12 years of age. The children study in an educational center in the community and his wife dedicate herself to household matters.

Juan has worked cutting cane since the age of ten. It's a job he decided to learn due to the same need that he still has, intending, initially, to help his parents. To reach work, he must walk several kilometers. His work hours are from 8:00 am until 4:00 pm every day.

The loan he is soliciting through our Institution will be used for purchasing school supplies for his children.

Juan's dream is that his children should be able to study a great deal in order to become professionals.

loans.use: to purchase school supplies for his children.

loans.name: Taatiamalepule

texts.en:
Taatiamalepule is 42 years old, with four children. To earn a living, she operates a business, selling bananas and taro in her community. She has been doing this for more than two years. 

Taatiamalepule has requested a loan to buy banana tubes, taro roots, a wheelbarrow, a water tank, hand-gloves, a rake, a shovel, and chemicals to assist her in running the business. 

She joined South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) in 2015 and she hopes to use her business profit to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy banana tubes, taro roots, a wheelbarrow, a water tank, hand-gloves, a rake, a shovel, and chemicals.

loans.name: Bertha

texts.es:
Bertha es una mujer de 50 años de edad, casada, tiene 1 hijo varón de 19 años, y su negocio es la venta de ropa de segunda mano.
Su negocio lo desarrolla en la zona ‘Villa Copacabana’ lugar caracterizado por los orígenes de sus habitantes; campesino aymaras que pelearon por la liberación del yugo español y se asentaron en ese lugar como trinchera, se encuentra sobre una ladera de la ciudad, donde las calles son pendientes y empinadas. De clima seco y frio, con una temperatura que varía durante el día entre 4-18 grados centígrados.
Bertha es de tez morena, cabello castaño largo lo usa estilo cola de caballo, baja estatura, complexión física robusta, su lengua materna es el Aymará que habla en familia y habla español por cultura general y por el comercio que realiza. Su vida la comparte con su esposo que trabaja en otro lugar y con su hijo que estudia en la escuela y hace deporte, viven en una casa alquilada construida de ladrillo que cuenta con agua potable, electricidad, gas domiciliario y alcantarillado. Su negocio es la venta de ropa de segunda mano; inicio su negocio vendiendo juguetes usados, más adelante incursionó vendiendo ropa de segunda mano; “el comercio es constante y la ropa que vendo tiene buen costo y tengo clientes constantes…” comenta. Su sueño es que su hijo sea profesional, ella desea invertir en su negocio mediante la compra de ropa de segunda mano por fardos para abastecerse de mercadería y satisfacer la demanda de temporada complaciendo a sus clientes. Esta es la 5 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 20 años que viene realizando esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Bertha solicita un préstamo para la compra de ropa de segunda mano por fardos para abastecerse de mercadería y fomentar los estudios de su hijo.
texts.en:
Bertha is a 50-year-old woman. He is married and has a 19-year-old son. Her business is selling secondhand clothing.

Her business is located in the “Villa Copacabana” area, which is a place characterized by the origins of its inhabitants, who are rural Aymaras who fought for liberation from the Spanish. They settled in this place as a trench, and found themselves on a hillside of the city, where the streets are sloped and steep. The area has a dry and cold climate, with a temperature that varied during the day between 4 and 18 degrees Celsius. 

Bertha has brown skin, brown hair that she wears in a ponytail, short stature, and a robust physique. Her mother tongue in Aymara, which she speaks with her family; she also speaks Spanish in everyday life and for her business. She shares her life with her husband, who works in another place, and with her son, who studies in school and does sports. They live in a rented house, built of brick that has drinking water, electricity, gas, and indoor plumbing. 

Her business is selling secondhand clothing. She started her business selling used toys. Later, she began selling secondhand clothing. She says that the business is stable, that the clothing that she sells is priced well, and that she has reliable clients. Her dream is that her son becomes a professional. 

She wants to invest in her business by buying secondhand clothing by the bundle to stock up on merchandise and to satisfy her clients’ seasonal demand. This is her 5th sequence of loan with the institution in the 20 years she has been doing this work.

It is for these reasons that Bertha requests a loan to buy secondhand clothing by the bundle to stock up on merchandise and support her son’s education.

loans.use: to buy a bundle of secondhand clothes.

loans.name: Praise Group

texts.en:
Viola is a member of Praise group, she lives in the Glen Norah suburb of Harare. Viola and her group members joined Thrive Microfinance in July 2014. She is into business of rearing egg layers. 

Viola says that she benefited significantly from the training and business advice she received from Thrive. On her first loan, Viola got $400 which she used to buy 100 egg laying chickens. She said she was happy after she got this loan as it improved her business; she started to produce 200 eggs a day from 50 a day she used to produce before she gets the loan.

Viola wishes to maintain a good relationships with Thrive microfinance so that she can continue benefiting. This time, Viola and her group members have applied for a combined loan amounting to $1850. She said she wants to use her proportion of the loan to increase the number of layers since there is high demand for eggs in her area. When asked her about her future, she said long term plan of buying an industrial stand so that she will expand her business and start to supply eggs to large supermarkets and restaurants. Viola also outlined that she is very grateful for the last loan that she received as it improved her business and her life.

loans.use: To increase her stock of egg layers.

loans.name: Havilla Group

texts.en:
Havilla group is a group of four united young mothers. They are based in Rugare, a high density suburb of Harare. 

Portia is the epitome of the old adage, “Dynamite comes in small packages”. Though small in stature, she is big in hard work and ambition. Portia is a cross border trader. She has been in the business for more than 4 years. She is married with 2 school going children. When she started her cross border business Portia used to restock from neighbouring South Africa. 

With her first loan from Thrive, Portia went as far as Tanzania to restock clothing for her business as she could get them cheaper there and get a wider variety. Her business has improved to the extent that with her profits they have managed to pay the deposit for a residential stand. With her 2nd loan, Portia is planning to go to Dubai to get a wider variety of material for her business. In future, Portia is planning to open a clothing shop, build her house and buy herself a car.

loans.use: To get a wider selection of clothing for resale.

loans.name: Yemurai Group

texts.en:
Losing her husband in 2009 made Tinarwo to be both mother and father to her children. She had to work extra hard since she was the family’s only source of livelihood. Tinarwo is a member of Yemurai group. She is a cross-border trader who started off by selling clothing, getting the items from South Africa, Botswana and Zambia. Tinarwo and her group members are in their 3rd loan cycle with Thrive. 

Tinarwo is grateful for the business training and loans from Thrive as they have helped her to grow her business. Tinarwo is now specializing in selling kitchenware that she restocks locally and in neighboring South Africa. Tinarwo’s business is indeed thriving as it is enabling her to pay rentals and take care of her children. She is now also an employer as she has someone working for her. Tinarwo has big dreams. She is planning to open other kitchen shops in different neighborhoods and one day buying a residential stand for herself and her children.

loans.use: To open a kitchen shop.

loans.name: Clara Elena

texts.es: Una cálida sonrisa caracteriza a Doña Clara, quien es una mujer trabajadora que comercializa pan y nacatamales desde hace 10 años. Está casada y su esposo ha sido su principal apoyo en todo momento. Doña clara, siempre ha pensado que la higiene de ella y su familia es de vital importancia, es por esta razón que solicita el crédito para poder realizar mejoras a su vivienda, las cuales, le permitirán tener mejores condiciones de vida. Las expectativas de esta mujer emprendedora son poder pagar este crédito para solicitar uno nuevo y seguir la construcción de su casa.
texts.en:
A warm smile characterizes Clara, who is a hard-working woman. She has sold bread and nacatamales (steamed corncakes) for 10 years. She is married, and her husband has been her main support all the time. 

Clara has always thought that cleanliness for her and her family is vital. It is for this reason that she requests a loan to be able to make improvements to her home. The improvements will allow her to have better conditions. 

The hopes of this enterprising woman are to be able to pay off this loan and to request a new one and continue building her house.

loans.use: to make improvements to her home.

loans.name: Vasande Group

texts.en:
Vasande group is comprised of four hardworking ladies based in the Kuwadzana suburb of Harare. They are from the same fellowship and know each other well. As a group, they were trained before applying for their loan. This will enable them to better manage their businesses especially when preparing simple income and expenditure accounts.

Patience, the group treasurer, is a widow with six children. She is an innovative tailor, mostly recognized for the unique designs she makes competing with other tailors in her neighborhood. She has been in the tailoring business since 2009. Her major challenge is lack of capital to renovate her workshop and to purchase sewing material in large quantities to benefit from economies of scale.

Her business is her only source of income, paying fees for her children and other family bills. With a loan of $300, she hopes to improve her business and thereby improving the standard of living for her children.

loans.use: To expand her tailoring business.

loans.name: Kugarika Group

texts.en:
Tsitsi is a member of Kugarika group, based in Crowborough high density suburb. She is a married woman with four children who sells ceramic tea sets and bowls from home. She restocks locally in Harare, and trades locally in nearby plots and rural areas. Tsitsi and her groupmates are in their 2nd loan cycle with Thrive Microfinance. With her first loan Tsitsi managed to grow her business and increase her profit levels. 

Tsitsi is now able to help her husband pay their children’s school fees and meet other household demands. Tsitsi's business has grown, and she now restocks more quantities than before. Tsitsi credits the training she got from Thrive for the growth and strengthening of her business. With her current loan, Tsitsi plans to restock more ceramic products for her business as demand from her customers is growing. In future, Tsitsi is planning to open a shop in the central business district specializing in Kitchenware.

loans.use: To expand her ceramic business.

loans.name: Yorling Arleja

texts.es:
Luchar cada día es lo que hace Yorlin para tener una vida mejor. Ella está muy agradecida con Kiva y Mi crédito, ya que el beneficio que obtuvo a través de su primer crédito fue grande, puesto que, por medio de este pudo invertir y comprar productos como arroz, botanas, huevos, etc. para ofrecer más variedad a los clientes de su pulpería. 

Nuevamente, Yorlin, solicita el crédito para comprar más mercadería tal como: Arroz, Frijoles, Aceite, Pan entre otros y de esta manera hacer crecer un poco más su negocio. Así mismo, para tener más beneficios y obtener mayores ganancias. Las expectativas de Yorlin son poder cancelar este crédito para luego solicitar uno nuevo que le permita mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Yorlin fights every day to have a better life. She is very thankful with Kiva and Mi Credito, since the benefits she obtained through her first loan were big. Through the loan, she was able to invest and buy products, such as rice, snacks, eggs, etc. to offer a larger variety to the clients of her grocery store.

Now, Yorlin requests a loan to buy more merchandise, including rice, beans, oil, and bread among other things. In this way, she will grow her business a little more. At the same time, she will be able to have more benefits and more earnings. Yorlin hopes to be able to repay this loan so that she can request another loan, which will improve the conditions of her home.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise, including rice, beans, oil, and bread among other things.

loans.name: Yamir Elvis

texts.es:
Yamir es un hombre joven de 20 años de edad, soltero, sin hijos y su negocio es la venta de material escolar de temporada.
Él es independiente, emprendedor, paciente, buen oyente, solidario, responsable  y trabajador. Su negocio lo realiza en la zona central, un área caracterizada por el comercio en todas las áreas, y que alberga a universidades, oficinas públicas y empresas privadas que conviven lado a lado, de clima frio y seco, con una temperatura ambiente entre 4-16 grados centígrados que varía durante el día. 
Yamir es de tez morena, baja estatura, cabello negro corto, complexión física delgada, ojos obscuros, su lengua materna es el Aymará que habla en familia, para el comercio habla español. Su vida la comparte con su hermana mayor que trabaja y con su hermano menor que también trabaja, su padre falleció hace varios años y su madre se fue a trabajar a Brasil hace 6 años y nunca más tuvieron noticias de ella. Viven en una casa en anticrético (especie de alquiler) que cuenta con agua potable, electricidad y alcantarillado. Su negocio es la venta de artículos de librería por temporada, como; lápices, bolígrafos, cuadernos, hojas blancas, papel de colores, reglas, marcadores, etc. En la temporada actual de inicio de año su comercio se dedicaba a la venta de agendas, la siguiente temporada es el inicio de clases escolares y se dedicará a la venta de mochilas escolares; Labor que realiza durante todo el día de lunes a domingo, su negocio tiene ventas constantes debido a que se encuentra cerca en pleno centro, “los artículos que vendo son exclusivamente por temporada, año nuevo vendo agendas, inicio de clases vendo mochilas escolares, Todo el año me la paso así, día que no trabajo es día que no como…” comenta. Su sueño es incrementar su mercadería para pagar los gastos de él y de sus hermanos. El desea abastecer su puesto de venta con material escolar de temporada como mochilas, para recibir el nuevo año escolar preparado con muchas mochilas. Esta es la primera secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 6 años que viene realizando esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Yamir solicita un préstamo para la compra de mochilas de temporada para ofertar al inicio del año escolar y con los beneficios cumplir su sueño de pagar los gastos de sus hermanos.
texts.en:
Yamir is a young man, who is 20 years old. He is single and doesn’t have any children. His business is selling seasonal school materials. 

He is independent, enterprising, patient, a good listener, supportive, responsible, and hard working. He pursues his business in the central area, an area characterized by business everywhere and an area that is home to universities, public offices, and private business that coexist side by side. The area is a cold and dry climate, with an outside temperature between 4 and 16 degrees Celsius that varies during the day.

Yamir has brown skin, short stature, short black hair, a thin physique, and dark eyes. His mother tongue is Aymara, which he speaks with his family; for work, he speaks Spanish. He shares his life with his older sister, who works, and with his younger brother, who also works. His farther passed away many years ago; his mother went to work in Brazil six years old, and they haven’t heard from her since. They live in a rented house that has drinkable water, electricity, and indoor plumbing. 

His business is selling seasonal school supplies, including pencils, pens, notebooks, blank paper, colored paper, rulers, markers, etc. In the current season around the beginning of the year, his business focuses on selling calendars. The next season is when school classes begin, and he will focus on selling school backpacks. He does this work all day from Monday to Sunday. His business has steady sales, because it is close to the central area. He says that the articles he sells are exclusively seasonal; in the new year, he sells agendas, and when classes begin, he sells school backpacks. He also says that the entire year passes in this way; a day that he doesn’t work is one in which he doesn’t eat. 

His dream is to increase his merchandise to pay for his and his siblings’ expenses. He wants to supply his selling stand with seasonal school supplies, like backpacks, so that he can begin the school year prepared with many backpacks to sell. This is his first sequence of loans with the institution in the 6 years he has been doing this work.

It is for these reasons that Yamir requests a loan to buy seasonal backpacks to sell at the beginning of the school year. With the returns, he will complete his dream of paying for his siblings’ expenses.

loans.use: to buy seasonal backpacks to sell at the beginning of the school year, so that he can achieve his dream of paying for his siblings' expenses.

loans.name: Namiz

texts.en:
Namiz is a 39-year-old, married man, from the village of Keshalo. He has a wife and two daughters and all of them are involved in an agricultural business. The family generates income from selling harvested products at the local market, which is the only source of income for them. 

Namiz works hard on family-owned agricultural land. He owns a greenhouse where he cultivates greens and vegetables. In order to meet the basic needs more effectively, Namiz has an intent to expand his agribusiness and to start farming. 

He requested a loan from local financial institutions and was approved within the joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up program gives a chance to rural people, like Namiz, who don't have access to credit products to start or re-start their own businesses. 

With the requested amount, Namiz plans to purchase cattle and to start selling meat at the local market. He will place the livestock in a newly-built cattle barn. Namiz will get the opportunity to generate significant income and create financial stability for his family. 

Namiz plans to invest the earnings from the loan in the further development of his business. He awaits your support.

loans.use: to buy cattle and start selling meat at the local market.

loans.name: Theodora Group

texts.en:
A widow, breadwinner and mother of five, Clara, is struggling to take care of her family. She relies on her vegetable selling business. Clara and her three friends doing small businesses in their community of Rugare Suburb in Harare formed a group called Theodora, and approached Thrive Microfinance for business support. 

She says that business has been very slow since she has very little capital to work with. She struggled to save monthly until she managed to apply for a passport. She then started to import clothes and electrical gadgets from South Africa as per order from her neighbours. This was in a bid to complement her vegetable selling business.  To date, Clara is getting a monthly profit averaged $166, from the cross border and vegetable selling businesses.
 
Clara is also working to advance her vegetable stall with a variety of fresh fruits, kapenta (small,dried fish) and small grains. With a loan of $200, she is going to improve her stocking capacity that will enable her to get a profit averaged $300 monthly. The other group members are pleased with the way her business has improved.

loans.use: To increase the range of goods for sale on her stall.

loans.name: Caylor Group

texts.en:
Lydia is a member of Caylor group. She is a mother of 2 and lives in Glen View, a suburb of Harare. Lydia is into the timber business. She buys timber from Mutare and sells them at a large local retail complex. Lydia said she joined Thrive Micro finance in December 2014 and she has benefited a lot from the training and business advice she received from Thrive. 

Lydia together with her other group members have applied for a loan amounting to $1300 dollars which they want to use to boost their businesses. Lydia wants to rent a large warehouse that she will be using to store her timber before it is sold to her customers as she wants to operate on a large scale after she has get a loan.

loans.use: to rent a warehouse for storing the timber she sells.

loans.name: Little Tots Group

texts.en:
Beverly, 41, is a member of the Little Tots group. The Little Tots group has four members who have been friends for many years. Beverly is a divorced mother of 3 children. She has been in the business of selling clothing and perfumes since 2009. Being business women, the Little Tots have for many years been sharing business ideas. They also have the Little Tots savings club where they try to save $20 per month. 

Although they are hardworking women, Beverly’s business was not growing. As a divorced mother, she found it difficult to maintain her business as well as take care of her family’s needs. She also had the additional burden of taking care of her father who is unemployed. After hearing about Thrive from her friends, Beverly and her group members joined Thrive. The training she received from Thrive taught her how to manage her finances. She is now able to make daily records of her business and save money more wisely. With a loan from Thrive, Beverly hopes to increase her stock and grow her business. She also hopes to maintain a good relationship with her group members and a trustworthy relationship with Thrive.

loans.use: To expand her stock of clothing for sale.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima, a widow with three children, lives in Kampala, Uganda, where she also takes care of additional family members (orphans). She lives in a home that she owns, and has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food for the family. 

For 12 years now, Halima has operated a business selling charcoal. Working seven days a week, she sells her products from home by means of wholesale/retail. She generates additional income by renting rooms and selling piped water. Her main business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. 

Halima has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal. Her goal is to develop more rental income.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en:
Meriam is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy-and-sell rice business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 2 years, though she also earns additional income from running a general store.

Meriam is borrowing 12,000 PHP through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation in order to buy sacks of rice to sell from her buy-and-sell rice business.

Meriam has already successfully repaid her previous loan, and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses. She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of loans from NWTF. 

Meriam dreams of building and expanding her business so she can secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy sacks of rice to sell from her business.

loans.name: Claudia

texts.es:
Claudia es una joven mujer de 25 años de edad, soltera, sin hijos, y estudia para ser profesora de escuela.
Ella es inteligente, emprendedora, alegre, constante y responsable. Sus estudios los desarrolla en la normal de ‘Warisata’ que se encuentra ubicado en cercanías al lago Titicaca, área agrícola dónde se cría ganado; vacuno, ovino, se vive de la pesca y también de vegetales, tubérculos y cereales del lugar, como la quinua, el chuño, la haba, la papa, etc. con una temperatura que varía durante el día entre 1-12 grados centígrados y donde los rayos solares golpean con mucha fuerza la superficie.
Claudia es de tez morena, baja estatura, viste de forma tradicional (sombrero, manta y pollera), su lengua materna es el Aymará que se habla en el lugar, habla español por cultura general y por los estudios que realiza. su vida la comparte con sus padres que se dedican a la agricultura, viven en una casa propia construida de adobe con techo de paja y cuenta con los servicios de electricidad y agua de pozo. Ella estudia para ser profesora de escuela, la base de sus estudios es en el idioma español y Aymará, esta escuela es la primera de este tipo que se desarrolló en el altiplano. Los alumnos que terminan sus estudios se dedican a alfabetizar a campesinos en áreas y lugares lejanos dónde sólo se llega caminando. Su sueño es terminar de estudiar y trabajar para ayudar a su familia, ella desea y necesita terminar de pagar sus estudios y realizar la compra de libros. Esta es la 2 segunda secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 5 años que viene realizando sus estudios.
Es por esos motivos que Claudia solicita un préstamo para terminar de pagar sus estudios y comprar libros para educar a niños de comunidades campesinas alejadas.
texts.en:
Claudia is a young woman aged 25. She is single, has no children, and is studying to become a school teacher.

She is intelligent, enterprising, happy, persevering and responsible. She is studying at a teachers college in Warisata, which is near to Lake Titicaca. It is an farming area, where cattle raising is common, and the people also make their livings from fishing, as well as farming locally grown vegetables, tubers and cereals, such as quinoa, chuño (artisanal freeze-dried potato), beans and potatoes etc. The temperature here varies during the day from 1 to 12° centigrade, and the suns rays beat down harshly on the earth.

Claudia is a short lady with a dark complexion, and wears the traditional hat, 'pollera' pleated skirt and a shawl known as a 'manta'. Her maternal language is Aymaran, which she speaks at home, but she also speaks Spanish, due to the general culture and for her studies. She lives with her parents, who work in farming, in a house they own themselves. The house is build from adobe, with a straw roof, and is supplied with electricity and well water. 

She is studying to become a school teacher, the basis of her studies is in Spanish and Aymaran language. This school is the first of its type to be developed in the Andean Plateau. The students who complete their studies here go on to teach reading and writing to people in remote locations which are only accessible on foot.

Her dream is to complete her studies and work so that she can help her family. She wants and needs to finish paying for her studies, and to buy books. This is the second loan with this institution in the five years that she has been studying.

It is for these reason that Claudia is requesting a loan, to finish paying for her studies, and to buy books to teach children in remote rural communities.

loans.use: to finish paying for her studies, and to buy books to teach children in remote rural communities.

loans.name: Maria Angela

texts.es: Maria de 36 años de edad vive en casa propia con su hermana, ella pose un comedor ubicado en su lugar de residencia desde hace varios, con lo que obtiene logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, ella quiere mejorar su vivienda  construyendo un cuarto y el baño en el lugar que muestra la fotografía, pero con lo que obtiene de sus ventas no le alcanza para realizarlo, por esa razón solicita un crédito para la compra de cemento, arena, ladrillos, hierro y pago de mano de obra para que ella y su hermana vivan mas seguras y cómodas.
texts.en:
Maria, 36, lives in her own house with her sister. For several years, she has had a restaurant located at her place of residence, with which she is able cover some of the expenses of her home.  She wishes to improve her residence constructing a room and a bathroom in the spot shown in the photograph, but with what she makes from her sales, it is not enough to make it happen.
For this reason, she is requesting a loan to buy cement, sand, bricks, rebar, and payment for the labor so that she and her sister can live more safely and comfortably.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, bricks, rebar, and payment for the labor.

loans.name: Nahum

texts.es: Nahúm de 33 años de edad vive en casa propia con sus padres, el se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras desde hace varios años, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra salir adelante, el quiere mejorar su vivienda cambiando el piso de cemento por cerámica, pero no tiene suficiente capital por esa razón solicita un crédito para la compra de cerámica, cemento y pago de mano de obra para que el su familia puedan vivir mas cómodos y en lo limpio.
texts.en:
Nahum, 33, lives in his own house with his parents.  He has been making a living selling fruits and vegetables for several years.  With what he earns from his sales, he is able to move forward.  He wants to improve his residence changing the cement floor for tile, but he doesn't have enough capital.
For this reason, he is requesting a loan in order to buy tile, cement, and payment for the labor so that his family can live more comfortably and in clean conditions.

loans.use: to buy tile, cement, and payment for the labor.

loans.name: Tươi

texts.en:
Mrs. Tươi works in agriculture growing industrial crops. She is 53 years old, and she is married with 4 children. She lives in Nong Cong district, a rural town in Thanh Hoá province, Vietnam.

This is Tươi's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She has been involved in her business for more than 10 years.

The main harship that Tươi faces in her life is not having a hygienic latrine. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase sand, cement, brick, and equipment to build a toilet.

With her business profits, Tươi hopes for her business to do well. She also hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, and for her children to find good jobs.

loans.use: to purchase sand, cement, brick, and equipment to build a toilet.

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion is 63 years old and is married with 3 children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. 

Salvacion is borrowing 25,000 PHP through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation in order to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. She has been raising pigs for 15 years and also earns additional income from selling frozen foods and running a general store.

Salvacion is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Tujinama Group

texts.fr:
Lucie  fait partie du groupe  Tujinama  et  habite à  Bujumbura. Elle a 45 ans et est mariée à Montfort, un commercant. Ensemble ils ont 4 enfants   tous étudient. 

Elle fait le commerce de boutique (riz, haricot, pains ...) depuis  7 ans. 

Elle est à son neuvième   crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’elle obtient, elle  va  augmenter son capital et acheter des articles de sa boutique en grande quantité (riz, haricot, pains,…) à revendre pour gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, elle voudrait  acheter une parcelle, et voir ses enfants étudier.
texts.en:
Lucie is a member of the Tujinama group and lives in Bujumbura. She is 45 years old and married to Montfort, an entrepreneur. They have four children, all of whom study.

Lucie has been running a grocery store selling rice, beans, bread  etc for seven years. She is on her ninth loan with Turame. With the Kiva credit, she will bolster her capital and restock her grocery store with goods (rice, beans, bread etc) for resale so as to increase her earnings.

loans.use: to restock her grocery store with items for sale so as to increase her earnings.

loans.name: Aterisa

texts.en:
Aterisa is 47 years old with 1 child. She operates a business selling bananas and taro in her community to earn a living. She has been doing this for more than 2 years. 

Aterisa has requested a loan in order to buy banana tubers, taro roots, chemicals, a wheelbarrow, water tank, rake, shovel, and hand gloves to help run  her business. 

Aterisa joined South Pacific Business Development in 2015, and she hopes to use her business profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy banana tubers, taro roots, chemicals, a wheelbarrow, water tank, rake, shovel, and hand gloves.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is single and has a food vending business in the Philippines.

Irene requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food business.

She has been in this business for four years now, and also earns additional income from raising chickens.

In the future, Irene would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food business.

loans.name: Renalie

texts.en:
As a married mother of two children, Renalie works hard to support her family.

She has a rice retailing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from retailing firewood. Renalie is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy more stock of rice to sell to customers.

Renalie has been sustaining her business activities through her past eleven loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy more stock of rice to sell.

loans.name: Apolonio

texts.es:
Apolonio, de 62 años de edad, estudió hasta tercer grado en la escuela de su comunidad, debido a la guerra civil que sufrió nuestro país, las escuelas las clausuraron y fue esa la razón por la cual no continuó estudiando, está acompañado y su pareja se dedica al comercio, tiene cuatro hijos, los cuales viven en su casa y le ayudan en los trabajos agrícolas.

Apolonio, se dedica a la siembra de granos básicos como frijol, maíz y arroz, desde que era pequeño su padre le enseño a realizar este trabajo y fue así como él aprendió a realizar esta actividad.- Además de dedicarse a la agricultura, en la época de verano se dedica a la venta de ropa con su esposa; ellos sale a vender  a distintos lugares, no tiene una sola ruta, ni horarios.

El crédito lo utilizará para comprar 1 docena de camisas para niños, 10 pantalones para caballero y 5 blusas para dama, esto le será de gran ayuda debido a que surtirá su tienda y así podrá obtener mejores ganancias. 

Apolonio, desea en un futuro hacer crecer su negocio y tener un local fijo; también sueña con tener un lugar más amplio para poder cultivar.
texts.en:
Apolino, 62, studied until the third grade at the community school.  However, due to the civil war that his country endured, the schools closed down and, for this reason, he could not continue studying.  He is in a common-law relationship, and his partner is engaged in trade.  He has four children who live at home, and they help him with the farm work.  

Apolino is engaged in sowing basic grains such as beans, corn, and rice.  When he was young, his father taught him how to do this work, and this is how he learned this activity.  In addition to engaging in agriculture, he is engaged in selling clothing with his wife. They go to different places to sell, but they don’t have a set route or schedule.  

He will use the loan to purchase one dozen children’s shirts, ten pairs of men’s pants, and five women’s blouses.  This will be a great help as he will stock his shop and thus earn higher profits.  In the future, Apolino wishes to grow his business and have a fixed location; he also dreams of having a larger area to farm.

loans.use: to purchase one dozen children’s shirts, ten pairs of men’s pants, and five women’s blouses.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es: El joven a quien se le ha pixeleado la cara por tener 23 años de edad y vivir en zona de alto riesgo, posee un taller de carpintería en el cual fabrica variedad de muebles, tiene muchos años de dedicarse al negocio y tiene muchos clientes porque ofrece calidad y buenos precios en sus muebles, el joven vive en casa propia con su compañera de vida, el está  solicitando un crédito  para la compra de madera, clavos, pega, barniz, junco y de más artículos para poder seguir con su trabajo y así tener una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: The young man whose face is blurred is 23 years old, and lives in a high risk area. He has a carpentry shop in which he makes a variety of furniture.  He has been engaged in this business for many years, and has many customers because he offers good prices and high quality on his furniture.  The young man lives in his own home with his life companion.  He is requesting the loan to purchase wood, nails, glue, varnish, rush, and other items to enable him to continue his work, and thus have a better quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase wood, nails, glue, varnish, rush.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es: El joven a quien se le ha pixeleado la cara por tener 27 años de edad y vivir en zona de alto riesgo, se dedica a la elaboración y venta de calzado desde hace 2 años, su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su lugar de residencia y tiene muchos clientes por la calidad del producto, el joven vive en casa propia con la abuela, el esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de cuero, hilo, pega, tela, etc. para seguir con su elaboración ya que esa es su única fuente de trabajo  y así tener junto con su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: This young man, whose face has been pixelated because he is 27 years old and lives in a zone of high risk, has been making and selling shoes for two years. He has located his business in his place of residence, and he has many customers because of the quality of his products. He lives in his own house with his grandmother. He is applying for a loan to purchase leather, thread, glue, fabric, etc., in order to continue with his production, since this is his only source of work, and to have, along with his family, a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy leather, thread, glue, fabric, ec.

loans.name: Makoka Group

texts.en:
Mustafa is in his early 40s, and he has 4 children who are all attending school. He sells fruits and vegetables and also has a motorcycle transportation business. He has been in this business for 6 years. He works daily from 7am to 10pm and is able to make a stable monthly profit. 

This will be Mustafa's sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. His previous loans were used to purchase fruits and vegetables for his stand, and he successfully repaid each loan. He has also been able to save some of the profits. 

With this loan, Mustafa plans to purchase a farm as well as more fruits and vegetables for his stand. He hopes to use the profits he earns to renovate his house and purchase food for his family. His dream is to one day own his own car so he can easily transport his produce.

Mustafa will be sharing this loan with his group, Makoka, which is made up of 5 individuals who will hold each other accountable for repaying the loan.

loans.use: to purchase a farm as well as fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Yeimi Melissa

texts.es:
Yeimi es una joven estudiante de Administracion de empresas, ella solicita un préstamo para poder cubrir sus gastos educativos, esta es su historia: Mi nombre es Yeimi, tengo 18 años de edad, vivo en Santo Domingo. Naci en San Juan en le pueblo de Vohechio y crecí allá hasta los 12 años, luego me mude a Santo domingo. Tengo una hermana de 17 u un hermano de 14 años.
Actualmente curso mis estudios en Administración de empresas en la Universidad Dominicana O&M, me gustaría ser una gran Administradora, estoy cursando el tercer cuatrimestre de mi carrera, la cual en el futuro me dará los frutos necesarios para mis sustento y el de mis familiares. En mi tiempo libre me gusta leer y compartir con mis familiares, sería un sueño para mi terminar mis estudios y ser una excelente profesional. 
Necesito este préstamo porque tengo una deuda pendiente con la universidad y por esta razón acudo a esta valiosa institución a solicitar el mismo, con la aprobación de este préstamo mi vida cambiaria totalmente ya que puedo estudiar tranquila y saber que no dejare mis estudios a un lado, en el futuro no muy lejano quiero ayudar a mis padres para que tengamos un mejor nivel de vida, por esta razón si no obtengo este préstamo suspendería mi matricula en la universidad.
Mis sueños a largo plazo es ser una profesional de éxito, poder lograr mis objetivos profesionales, alcanzar un buen nivel laboral, tener oportunidades nuevas y competitivas para el mercado laboral y estar a la altura del mismo. Me gustaría trabajar para una empresa de diseño en donde la creatividad juegue un papel importante en la misma, ya que son una chicha muy creativa y proactiva.
texts.en:
Yeimi is a young business administration student who is requesting a loan to cover her educational expenses.  This is her story: My name is Yeimi, and I am 18 years old.  I live in Santo Domingo. I was born in San Juan in the town of Vohechio where I grew up until I was 12.  Later, I moved to Santo Domingo.  I have a 17 year-old sister and a 14 year-old brother.

I am now enrolled in a business administration program at the Universidad Dominicana O & M.  I would like to become a great manager.  I am now in the 3rd quarter of my degree program which, in the future, will give me the means to support myself and my relatives.  In my free time, I enjoy reading and spending time with family.  My dream is to finish my education and become an excellent professional.

I need this loan because I have an existing debt with the university, and so this is why I have come to this valuable institution to request a loan.  With the approval of this loan, my life will change completely, as I will be able to study tranquilly, knowing that I won't have to put my studies aside. In the near future, I want to help my parents so that they can have a better quality of life.  But if I cannot obtain this loan, I will have to suspend my enrollment in the university.

In the long run, my dream is to become a successful professional so that I can achieve my professional goals and advance professionally.  I hope to have new and competitive opportunities in the labor market, and rise to the top.  I would like to work for a design company where creativity plays an important role, because I am a very creative and proactive young woman.

loans.use: to pay for the cost of higher education

loans.name: Carmencita

texts.en:
Carmencita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines.

She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

Carmencita has been in this business for ten years. She earns more income from selling ready-to-wear clothes.

Carmencita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.
